item.title: Men's Health Awareness Month
item.description:
Men's Health Month raises awareness of the critical aspects of men's healthâ€”physical, mental, and social connection.

Men's Physical Health

Visit menshealthmonth.org to download a men's health checklist.

A complete list of recommended adult vaccinations is available from the CDC: cdc.gov.

Men's Mental Health

Mental health significantly influences overall well-being. Men are less likely to seek help but must recognize and address symptoms of depression and anxiety. Open conversations about mental health can reduce stigma.

The Importance of Social Connection

Strong social connections are vital for health. Loneliness increases the risk of heart disease, dementia, stroke, depression, and anxiety. Building and maintaining social connections can improve overall health and reduce premature mortality. Even simple actions, such as contacting friends or community volunteering, greatly benefit mental well-being.

Men's Health Month encourages proactive health management. Contact a provider today for health screenings and assessments.

item.title: 10 Early Signs & Symptoms of Alzheimer's & Dementia
item.description:
Memory loss disrupting daily life may indicate Alzheimer's or dementia. Recognize these early signs and schedule an appointment with your doctor if noticed.

  1. Memory loss disrupting daily life
  2. Challenges in planning or solving problems
  3. Difficulty completing familiar tasks
  4. Confusion with time or place
  5. Trouble understanding visual images and spatial relationships
  6. New problems with words in speaking or writing
  7. Misplacing things and losing ability to retrace steps
  8. Decreased or poor judgment
  9. Withdrawal from work or social activities
  10. Changes in mood and personality

If you or a loved one shows these symptoms, consult a healthcare professional promptly.

item.title: 10 Healthy Habits for Your Brain
item.description:
Adopting these healthy habits can significantly lower your risk of cognitive decline and dementia, especially important for individuals with a family history.

  • Challenge your mind with new activities and learning.
  • Stay in school or continue education.
  • Protect your head to avoid brain injury.
  • Control blood pressure through medication and healthy habits.
  • Eat a balanced diet rich in healthy foods.
  • Be smoke-free to lower cognitive decline risk.
  • Manage diabetes through a healthy lifestyle.
  • Maintain a healthy weight to support brain health.
  • Get moving with regular exercise.
  • Sleep well, prioritizing quality sleep.

Visit alz.org/healthyhabits for more tips and information.
